Posts.Content: Jul 12, 2008 08:31AM cestovatela wrote: You're definitely doing the right thing by getting this checked out!  I am sorry about your insurance company. Maybe visiting the breast surgeon will be better for your mental health though.  MRI's can show a lot of false positives, which would be nerve-wracking.  Maybe you should call the surgeon's office to see what to expect -- is this a consultation or a biopsy?  If it's a biopsy, will it be excisional (where they put your under anasthesia and remove the whole lump) or core needle (where they use a needle to suck up a sample of the tissue)? As a lot of women here will tell you, 80% of breast lumps are benign.  I just had a big scare with a fibroadenoma.  Two doctors had told me it felt just like a cyst, so I dragged my feet to the breast center for a mammogram.  Then suddenly we were talking about a solid mass of "abnormal size for benign growth" and "borders irregular upon magnification."  It had grown more than I realized because it had grown downward into my breast where I could not feel it.  Still turned out to be benign and I feel the amount I have learned about health and breast health was perhaps worth all the scares.  You are absolutely doing the right thing by checking it out and since it's growing, it needs to be removed anyway.  In the meantime, I hope that you are able to stay busy and keep distracted.  Don't feel bad about asking your doctor for anxiety meds if you need them :)
Posts.Title: Lump in Rt Breast Tammychat Tammychat

Posts.Content: Jul 3, 2008 05:39PM cestovatela wrote: http://www.breastcancer.org/symptoms/testing/mri.jsp  Here is a link to some information about MRI guided biopsy.  You will have to copy and paste into your address bar as I could not make a clickable link.    http://www.breastcancer.org/symptoms/testing/biopsy.jsp The bottom of this page has info on excisional biopsies.  It sounds like an outpatient procedure, so I doubt you would be out of work for very long, if at all.    I am waiting for biopsy results now and I understand how scary it is.  The radiologist told me that the size/shape of the mass determines how the rate it on their scale of suspiciousness.  If you want more information, you could always call and ask for it.  I was afraid I would be bothering people with my questions, but I was amazed at how friendly my local breast center was.  Your GP should also be able to explain basic things like what makes a mass suspicious or not. My best lesson from all this waiting is not to research.  The ensuing sleepless nights and days of worrying are not worth it.  Knowing every single possibility is not empowering; it is terrifying.  Call your doctor for sleeping pills or anti anxiety medications, stay busy, tell a few close friends and try to have some fun.  If your diagnosis is bad, you will have plenty of time to discover everything about it.  Stick around these forums for support instead - the ladies here really are helpful!
Posts.Title: 25 w nipple bleed & mass/ MRI loc. excision. biposy erin1 charmed-imsure

Posts.Content: Jul 4, 2008 10:57PM cestovatela wrote: The doctor never bothered to call today.  I'm so upset!  I was surprised when she assured me over and over again that she would call me on Friday, a holiday -- I didn't expect that level of consideration at all.  If she had said that I would need to wait till Monday, I would have been fine.  But if you say repeatedly that you will absolutely, positively call on Friday, you'd better do it!  I am pushing down the sliver of fear that says she chose not to call me because the results were malignant and she wanted me to come to her office on Monday.  I still managed to have an excellent evening and I will just have to hang on for the rest of the weekend I suppose.
Posts.Title: Waiting for biopsy for 2 inch tumor cestovatela Beth1128

Posts.Content: Aug 4, 2008 06:21PM cestovatela wrote: I had a similar situation earlier this year, though without the discharge.  My first GP was sure it was nothing, told me to come back if it grew.  My second GP sent me for a mammo ASAP.  What I thought was a small lump turned out to have grown deeper into a part of my breast that I couldn't feel.  I heard a lot of scary terms like "areas of regular borders" and "unusually large for a benign lump."  It still turned out to be a fibroadenoma.

Posts.Title: Waiting for biopsy for 2 inch tumor cestovatela Beth1128

Posts.Content: Jul 3, 2008 05:20PM cestovatela wrote: I had my core needle biopsy today.  Getting the numbing injections stung quite a bit, but beyond that, I literally felt nothing.  I was shocked when she told me that she had just taken a sample because I did not even feel the pressure of the needle going in.  That was even after she'd been concerned that she wouldn't be able to fully numb me because the lump was so big.  The only slight complication was that the lump moved around so much that she had a hard time cornering it to get all the samples she wanted.  I do feel better because when I asked what made it different from most fibroadenomas, she said it was round rather than an oval.  Somehow that is less scary than what I imagined.  I will be getting test results by phone tomorrow and I feel significantly less terrified after getting a full night's sleep for the first time since my suspicious mammogram.  Calling the doctor for sleeping pills was probably the best decision I made all week!
Posts.Title: Waiting for biopsy for 2 inch tumor cestovatela Beth1128

Posts.Content: Jul 7, 2008 09:42AM cestovatela wrote: I don't have cancer!  Instead, I have a giant (apparently that's a real medical description) fibroadenoma with an atypical appearance.  I will have it removed promptly for peace of mind. As someone suggested earlier, it was not quite as big as I thought it was.  It measured 2 cm (about 1.8 in) on the ultrasound, which is still large, but only half as big as I expected.
Posts.Title: Waiting for biopsy for 2 inch tumor cestovatela Beth1128

Posts.Content: cestovatela wrote: I am 26 years old and terrified.  I've had this lump for nearly 18 months now.  I found it when I was living in Tokyo and the doctor told me because I'm young and the lump is smooth, round and movable, I could have it taken care of when I returned to the United States.  There would have been huge language barriers in Japan and worse, the Japanese idea of how medicine should be practiced is quite different from the American one.  So I waited.  And the wait mushroomed -- I got back to America but had a hard time finding a job (and thus insurance), then when I finally got hired, a paperwork snafu meant I didn't get insurance for nearly 6 months.   My GP felt my lump, said it wasn't very worrisome and sent me off for a "just in case" mammogram.  The radiologist surprised me by requesting a biopsy.  She said that it looks more like a fibroadenoma than cancer, but that its shape was slightly abnormal.  I will have an ultrasound-guided needle core biopsy on Thursday. I am scared just because of how large the tumor is.  From everything I've read, it would probably be a Stage III cancer, which is terrifying for someone my age.  It is so hard not to let my thoughts race ahead to the worst.  I got through today okay, but now that it's night time, I can feel the panic setting in.  There are so many what-if's!  It helps to read all the posts here.  It sounds like everyone who's been in this position has been equally terrified. After reading some other posts here, I can see that I've been lucky in how quickly I've been able to schedule all these tests.  I was able to get in for a mammogram and ultrasound in less than a week.  After the mammogram, instead of having to wait for a formal report, they let me speak directly with a radiologist to hear her preliminary thoughts.  Since I was visibly upset, the radiologist then helped me schedule the biopsy appointment just 3 days after the mammogram.  Within an hour of my appointment, a nurse from the office called to outline *exactly* what the biopsy would be like and she patiently answered all of my very detailed questions.  The doctor who is performing the biopsy even agreed to call me with the results even though they will arrive on the 4th of July, when the office is closed.  These are clearly caring people and part of a dedicated breast center at my local hospital, so if the worst comes, I think I will get good care.  It is still scary, but it's soothing to remind myself of these things. Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Waiting for biopsy for 2 inch tumor cestovatela Beth1128

Posts.Content: Jul 16, 2008 07:37PM - edited Jul 16, 2008 07:38PM by cestovatela I convinced my mammo and ultrasound tech tell me a little bit about what they saw, but in retrospect, this was not the best decision.  They were correct that the doctor would want a biopsy, but they didn't have the expertise to evaluate the pictures properly, so I think they scared me more than necessary.  I did ask if I could talk to the radiologist after my appointment and she explained why she wanted the biopsy (which turned out to be benign, btw.)  Breast MRI's are usually given if the ultrasound will not work well for some reason, like if the breasts are too dense to be visualized fully or there's a palpable mass (that means a mass that you can feel) that won't show up.  They are also sometimes given after cancer is diagnosed to be sure that all of the cancer is found before surgery or chemo.  However, MRI's are not usually the "first resort" because (a) they are expensive (b) they frequently return false positives, which means you end up with more stress and more biopsies than you actually need.
Posts.Title: New Appointment greenThumbs greenThumbs

Posts.Content: Jul 12, 2008 10:50AM cestovatela wrote: I did the same thing when I found my breast lump.  I was sure that I was too young for it to be cancerous and certain that some annoying doctor would demand I have it surgically removed when I didn't want it to be.  Flash forward 18 months and the sucker hand grown on me quite a bit. I did not even realize it was growing because it grew downward to a place I couldn't feel in my breast. Luckily, it turned out to be benign, but I had a much bigger scare than I otherwise would have.  If I had gone in when it was smaller, the doctor would've said "this is very small and looks just like a fibroadenoma, although we'll get a biopsy just to be safe."  Instead, she said "this seems like a fibroadenoma, but it's abnormally large for a benign growth so we defnitely need a biopsy."  That was terrifying!  Now I know that I will need it removed, but it is too large to get out with just a needle.  Since it is almost an inch long, I am now much more worried about a long scar from the surgical incision or a big dent in my breast where it comes out.  I wish I had dealt with it earlier so I wouldn't have these cosmetic concerns.
Posts.Title: How do i talk to my girlfriend janined86 janined86

Posts.Content: Jul 11, 2008 04:25PM cestovatela wrote: I don't know if there's a standard magnification.  They probably have a few settings.  Microcalcifications might be magnified a lot since they're so small. I didn't realize the images were magnified at all on the mammo/ultrasound, which is part of how I scared myself so badly.  I thought what I was looking at was actual size. Funny story:  I actually spent a restless night trying to pinch my lump between my fingers and measure it.  I woke up with red, inflamed skin and lots of swollen half moon marks over the lump.  My immediate thought was, of course, OH GOD INFLAMMATORY BREAST CANCER before I calmed down and remembered what I was doing the night before.  Thank goodness it cleared up before the biopsy - I would have been so mortified to tell the doctor!
Posts.Title: How much is a "Spot Mag" Magnified? therese48 cestovatela

Posts.Content: Jul 12, 2008 02:00PM cestovatela wrote: Yes, I had a BIRAD 4 and a ultrasound guided core needle biopsy.  I heard lots of scary words like "abnormally large" and "atypical appearance," but it still turned out okay.  Now I am happy to know that I have doctors who don't take chances with my health!

Posts.Content: cestovatela wrote: Hello ladies!   While awaiting my biopsy results, I've become strangely addicted to research.  I am counting on my results being normal and I would really like to do something as a thank you to the wonderful women who've supported me here.   I noticed that a lot of people post here with trouble understanding reports they've received from mammograms and ultrasounds.  Would it be helpful if I compiled a list of vocab words so that people could come to one place and look them up?  I already have lots of words/defintions and would love to create a post for this.  If we agreed that the final product was useful, I could PM a moderator to see if it could be made into a sticky, or I could just keep the link in my profile so people could always find it easily. I'm going to list the words I already know below.  I hope others will chime in with words that should be added to the list.  1. Cyst 2. Complex cyst 3. Septated 4. Lobulated 5. Spiculated 6. Hypoechoic 7. Fibroadenoma 8. Shadowing/Acoustic shadowing Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Would a vocab list be helpful? cestovatela cestovatela

Posts.Content: Jul 4, 2008 10:47AM cestovatela wrote: I would guess you are in for a needle core biopsy guided by either ultrasound or MRI.  Excisional biopsies, which involve a kind of simple surgery, would have some preparation requirements for you.  At least as I understand it, people need to fast before going under a general anasthetic and sometimes bloodtests are done, so I'm certain they would warn you about it beforehand. I had a core needle biopsy yesterday and the anxiety was worse than the actual procedure.  Getting the numbing injections stung badly, but after that I literally felt nothing.  The soreness I felt afterward has been easy to control with Tylenol.  I think the most pain I've felt since the procedure was when I pulled off the tape holding down the gauze!
Posts.Title: Is an operation on the cards? charmed-imsure Shirlann

Posts.Content: Jul 3, 2008 08:26PM cestovatela wrote: Just wanted to let other ladies know that I had a core needle biopsy today and it was not painful in the least.  I was a little scared after reading this post because I do frequently have trouble getting numb at the dentist, but the procedure was fine.  The lidocaine injection stung very badly, but after that, I did not even feel the pressure of the needle going in.  This was after the doctor was concerned that she wouldn't be able to fully numb me because the lump is large. One piece of advice:  if you are nervous or scared, tell people!  I think a lot of doctors and nurses fall into the trap of "just another day at the job" and because these procedures are routine for them, they forget that they are NOT routine for us.  The doctor and nurse were both a bit robotic at first, but when I told them that I was anxious about both the procedure and the test results, they were kind, friendly and reassuring.  It is frustrating that you have to remind them of your humanity, but don't assume that you won't get help/kindness if you ask for it.
Posts.Title: Core Biopsy Pain Estepp suems

Posts.Content: Jul 3, 2008 09:50PM cestovatela wrote: Donna,  Of course I don't mind your asking!  I posted this to help people :)  I'd describe what I feel as discomfort rather than pain.  My whole breast is sort of ache-y, but not nearly as bad as what I got when I started taking birth control pills.  I get stronger twinges when I raise my arm over my head or lie on my side and I am taking extra strength Tylenol religiously.  I can definitely tell when it starts to wear off.  As per doctor recommendation, I am also keeping ice packs on it until bedtime.  This means no going out in public as I look like I have a weird Dolly Parton-sized uniboob, but it definitely helps.  I get my results back tomorrow.  The radiologist agreed to call me with the pathologist's findings even though it is a holiday.  She was kind of blase about the whole thing at first, but when she saw that I was worried about waiting, she immediately offered to call me tomorrow.  That is what I mean about getting kindness when you ask for it!
Posts.Title: Core Biopsy Pain Estepp suems

Posts.Content: Aug 6, 2008 01:34PM cestovatela wrote: A mammogram is usually the first test.  If your breasts are dense, they may ask for an ultrasound as well.  You would definitely not have any other procedures at your initial appointment.  For anything even remotely invasive, they have to give you instructions, make sure you're not taking anything that would thin your blood, etc. etc.

Posts.Content: Jul 14, 2008 08:01PM cestovatela wrote: Many states have insurance programs that are specific to women's health issues.  I know that my state, Oklahoma, has a specific program that pays for treatment of breast and cervical cancer.  If you are comfortable posting your state here, some other ladies might have information specific to your location.
Posts.Title: insurance V speedy diagnosis/care Concerned-222 Concerned-222

Posts.Content: Jul 11, 2008 11:00AM cestovatela wrote: I have been following these boards for only 2 weeks and have already seen several women post with a large number of lumps in one or both breasts.  Some people are just pre-disposed to that.  That said, since you have insurance, there is no reason not to get them checked out, especially if they are hurting you. Cysts can cause pain as they fill up and other types of benign lumps can press on your nerves if they're in a bad place, which can cause pain.  My fibroadenoma hurt with my menstrual cycle, which is one reason I plan to have it removed.  Your doctor can probably biopsy all of the lumps at once, probably with a need core procedure that uses a large needle to suck up small tissue samples from each lump.  You will get a numbing injection beforehand, which is the only part of the procedure that hurts.   I think I have learned a valuable lesson this summer about ignoring breast lumps.  I had mine for a year and half before I got it checked out.  There were some extenuating circumstances, but at least half of it was laziness and disbelief that anything could be wrong with me.  It turned out that I could only feel a small portion of the large lump that had grown in my breast, and I did not know that the deeper part had more irregular borders.  It still turned out to be benign (a fibroadenoma), but I will not be doing my own watch-and-wait on lumps anymore.
Posts.Title: Life sentence, even with no cancer? theonlyfalco AnnNYC

Posts.Content: Jul 10, 2008 10:35AM cestovatela wrote: Personally, I would stick with the needle biopsy because you can get it scheduled quickly, which means results quickly, which means peace of mind.  Chances are, you will need to have it out anyway (removal of lumps is usually recommended for women 40 and over), but if it's benign, you can take your time about finding a surgeon you really like.  Besides, if you go into surgery knowing the lump is benign, the doctor should only remove the minimum tissue necessary.  If you know it's something more serious, they can make a plan to take out as much as they need.  Having a surgeon go in "blind" sounds undesirable to me. I would have regretted driving myself to my biopsy.  The seatbelt in my car tended to rub painfully against my biopsy spot, and controlling it while also steering the car would've been challenging.   If your biopsy incision will be on the outside of your breasts, you might also have to contend with your arms brushing against it as you steer.  Plus, it's just nice to have someone waiting for you to coddle you when you finish :)
